4.4 The Sonnet

        Completion requirements
        



The King of the Fixed Form
The sonnet is the gold standard of fixed verse poetry.  The Italians have their own version of it, called the Plutarchian Sonnet.  The British have their own version, called the Spenserian Sonnet.  Shakespeare famously wrote 118 sonnets
    about love, life, and the English Renaissance.  
In general, most sonnets are one stanza, have 14 lines long, and have a fixed line length, usually 10 syllables.  Most are written in iambic pentameter, five sets of unstressed, stressed syllables.  Even though they are one
    stanza, most sonnets can be divided into two parts, the octave (first eight lines), which describes a problem or cause, and the sestet (last six lines), which offers a solution or effect.  In the middle, of course,
    if a transition, or a volta (Italian for "turn").  Usually, a volta begins the 9th line (the first line of the sestet) with a word like "But", "So", or some shift in tone.    Often, a sonnet will end with a
    couplet, a pair of rhyming lines, to make it more memorable. 
Before the Statue of Liberty was installed near Ellis Island, New York, a sonnet was commissioned as a dedication to American immigration, liberty, and democracy.  Emma Lazarus' sonnet (below) is engraved in bronze at the base of Lady Liberty and
    has become the most famous American sonnet:
